pageData.text:
Individual bacterial cells are commonly described as (rod-shaped), (spherical), and spiral. But the growth of colonies of and other microorganisms can be much more complex. Colonies are often described as being raised, smooth, flat, filamentous, irregular, circular, etc. Some bacteria can form macro-colonies that form multiple patterns. Tal Danino is a synthetic biologist at the Synthetic Biological Systems Lab at New York City’s Columbia University. He is trying to understand what environmental conditions stimulate different growth patterns in microbial colonies. He hopes that by finding the cues that the colonies use to communicate and survive, he can use that knowledge to fight cancer1.1D'Arcy, P. (2017). pageData.text: are prokaryotic organisms, meaning that each is a single cell, which lacks a nucleus or other membranous organelles. Bacteria are perhaps best known as : microorganisms that cause infectious diseases such as strep throat, gonorrhea, and Lyme disease. However, only a fraction of bacterial species cause infections in humans. Most do not adversely affect us, and in fact, many are beneficial.

Whether trying to diagnose a potential bacterial infection or monitor bacterial cultures used in food production, it is vital to be able to identify the species which are present. There are numerous tests available to help identify bacteria, but the first step is often microscopic examination. One of the first clues in trying to identify unknown bacteria is cell shape. The three most common bacterial cell shapes are , , and spiral. Oftentimes, the characteristic cell shape of a bacterial species appears in its scientific name. For example, Lactobacillus acidophilus has a characteristic bacillus shape. The rest of the name refers to the “acid-loving” nature of the bacterium, which grows best at a lower pH, as well as its ability to produce lactic acid by fermentation.

A bacillus is a rod-shaped cell. Multiples are called . They usually occur either singly (Figure 1) or in chains of cells that adhere to one another (), depending on the species. Many bacilli can move about their environment with the use of long, slender appendages called , as seen in Figure 1. Lactobacillus acidophilus is an example of a beneficial bacillus species.

This natural inhabitant of the human gastrointestinal tract and vagina helps to protect against the overgrowth or invasion of potentially harmful microbes. Escherichia coli also inhabits the lower portion of the human gastrointestinal tract and is generally beneficial, although there are strains that can cause food poisoning. Other harmful bacilli include: Bacillus anthracis, which causes anthrax; Clostridium, which causes tetanus; and certain members of the genus Salmonella, which cause a type of food-borne illness known as salmonellosis.

pageData.text: A is a spherical cell. Multiples are called . They may occur singly, but more commonly adhere to one another in pairs, chains, or even clusters (Figure 3), of varying size depending on the species. Most cocci species lack . Strep throat is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of infections of the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and respiratory tract.

One strain, known as MRSA (short for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) is of great concern because of its resistance to treatment with the antibiotic methicillin as well as similar drugs. Gonorrhea, a sexually-transmitted bacterial infection, is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Streptococcus thermophilus is often used (along with certain members of the Lactobacillus genus) to convert milk into yogurt.

pageData.text: There are two types of spiral <button class='glossary-text'>bacteria</button>. Both occur singly, not adhering to one another, and are shaped like springs or coils. It is easiest to distinguish between them when they are living due to the way the cells move.

A (plural, ), like the example in Figure 4, is relatively large for a bacterium, and rigid. If it is able to move, it does so with the use of that extend from both ends of the spiral. Spirillum volutans is a natural inhabitant of stagnant freshwater, and does not cause disease in humans. It is known for being one of the largest known bacterial species: a single cell may be 60 μm long.

pageData.text: A (plural, spirochetes) is more flexible than a spirillum, and moves with a distinctive twisting motion due to the internal location of its flagella. Treponema pallidium is the causative agent of the sexually-transmitted infection syphilis. Borrelia burgdorferi causes Lyme disease, a tick-borne infection. Figure 5 depicts Borrelia spirochetes in a blood sample. The larger, round, red objects are red blood cells.

pageData.text: In this investigation, you will use a virtual microscope to examine an example of each of the three common bacterial shapes. The bacterial cells have been applied to the surface of the slide in three separate, roughly circular “smears.” They were then fixed—a step that simultaneously kills and preserves the cells, while making them adhere to the slide, and then stained with dye to make them easier to see. One smear on the slide contains , and another to represent spiral-shaped , there is a third smear consisting of .

Note: All three smears have been stained with the same dye, which enables the identification of cell shape. It will not be possible to clearly view cell appendages such as ; these are only made visible with special staining and/or microscopy techniques. Please be aware that bacterial cells may naturally adhere to one another. Also, most smears are not completely uniform. There are often thick clumps of cells in one or more areas of the smear. Plan to view each smear carefully to distinguish individual cells.
